questions.text: A 45 year old female presented with menorrhagia and episodes of mucocutaneous bleeding. Platelet count was found to be 21000 cells/mm3.There was no splenomegaly.ANA was found to be positive. A provisional diagnosis of secondary ITP was considered. This kind of Autoimmune destruction of platelets is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All the above Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP) It is an autoimmune disorder due to the presence of auto- antibodies directed against platelet membrane glycoprotein IIb and IIIa resulting in premature removal of platelet by macrophage monocyte system. Cause of Autoimmune Thrombocytopenia:- Idiopathic - ITP Secondary SLE Lymphoma, CLL HIV Drugs Solid tumors Clinical Features of ITP:- In children: Typically presents 2 – 3 weeks after a viral infection with sudden onset of purpura, nasal or oral bleeding. In adults: ITP involves females more commonly and has insidious onset. Symptoms and signs of collagen vascular disorders (like rheumatoid arthritis) may be present. The course is chronic with remissions and relapses. Splenomegaly and bleeding in the joints are not the features of ITP. In ITP, BT is prolonged but CT is normal. Investigation:- P/S = large platelet, isolated thrombocytopenia with normal TLC and RBC count In ITP, BT is prolonged but CT is normal USG= spleen not enlarged BM = increase thromboblast megakaryocytes Management:- In children, the disease is usually self – limiting within a few weeks. Drugs therapy:- Prednisolone best initial treatment Intravenous immunoglobulin (it is the fastest to act in acute and severe bleeding. It prevents activation of macrophages. It is not given in Rh negative patients) Rituximab: It is used if a patient is not responding to prednisolone and I/V immunoglobulin. Splenectomy If count < 20,000 /ml and recurs repeatedly despite giving above therapies.

questions.text: During your regular clinical posting in final year, your professor is discussing with you the mechanism of immune hemolytic anemia. One such mechanism was an innocent bystander mechanism. Which of the following correctly describes the above mechanism?

options.label: A
options.text: Antibody directed against the RBC antigen

options.label: B
options.text: Antibody directed against drug molecules and red cells get involved in the reaction

questions.correct_answer: B. Antibody directed against drug molecules and red cells get involved in the reaction
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Antibody directed against drug molecules and red cells get involved in the reaction. Innocent bystander mechanism is correctly explained by statement B as in this, the antibody is not directed against RBC, rather they get involved in reaction between antibody and other antigen like drugs.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option A: Antibody directed against RBC antigen explains the theory of autoimmune hemolytic anemia. Option C: Antibody directed against RBC-hapten complex explains the hapten model where hapten acts as an immunogenic molecule .

questions.text: A 24 year old male patient with weakness, jaundice and splenomegaly underwent Lab investigations which revealed- Hb- 10 gm%, MCV normal, reticulocyte count increased. The P/S revealed the following finding. He underwent a splenectomy after which the shape of RBC became normal after some time. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

AIHA After splenectomy , the shape of the RBC turned normal. Hence, the diagnosis for this patient will be AIHA.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Hereditary spherocytosis- t he clinical features are similar as compared to AIHA but after splenectomy the shape of the RBC will remain same as it is a hereditary condition Option: C. Hereditary elliptocytosis is not the answer as we see the shape as spherocytes in the P/S. Option: D. Megaloblastic anemia is an incorrect answer as the MCV is not raised and retic count would have been decreased which is not the case in this patient.

questions.text: A 55 Year old male patient was brought to hospital with the loss of consciousness. On examination, pallor , icterus and splenomegaly were noted. He was recently diagnosed with CLL for which he was started on treatment. Lab investigation revealed anemia with increased retic count, increased unconj. Bilirubin. Direct coomb’s test was positive. Which of the following is the likely P/S finding in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

C. In the given case, the patient with CLL with features of hemolytic anemia showing direct coombs test positive. The most likely diagnosis is a warm antibody type of autoimmune hemolytic anemia. Hence, the P/S in image C shows spherocytes which are seen in AIHA.

questions.text: A 24 year old male recently suffered from sore throat, cervical Lymphadenopathy and fever. Monospot test was positive. After receiving treatment and recovering, he again visited hospital with complaints of dark coloured urine, pain in the ear lobule and bluish discoloration on exposure to cold. His Lab investigations revealed- ANEMIA with increased retic count. Which of the following antibody is involved in this condition considering the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

IgM The given clinical scenario with patients with history suggesting infectious mononucleosis in the past and now anemia with intravascular hemolysis points toward the diagnosis of Cold agglutinin type of AIHA. Hence, the type of antibody involved in this condition is IgM type. So the answer will be option B.

Highyeild:

Patterns of direct antiglobulin (direct Coombs) test in autoimmune hemolytic anemias Type of hemolysis Pattern of positivity Antigen Comments Warm AIHA Anti-IgG and/or anti- C3 Rh complex antigens or glycoprotein antigens Usually IgG (rarely IgA or IgM): typically panagglutinins Drug-induced AIHA Anti-IgG and/or anti- C3 Drug plus RBC antigen or Rh complex Usually IgG (rarely IgM) Cold agglutinin disease Anti-C3 I or i antigen IgM; agglutinates RBCS Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria Anti-C3 P antigen IgG; fixes complement in the cold; hemolysis occurs when the sample is warmed (Donath-Landsteiner antibody)

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. IgG is involved in warm autoimmune type of autoimmune hemolytic anemia. Option: C. IgA is not involved in AIHA. Option: D. both IgG and IgM is not the correct answer as they are not involved together.
